The meaning of this verse is
My obeisances are unto you
who are the property of the materially impoverished.
You have nothing to do with the actions and reactions
to the material modes of nature.
You are self-satisfied
and therefore you are the most gentle
and you are the master of the monas.

I had to give up my possessions, I had to give up my everything. But we should also understand
that we cannot really be a renouncer in that way. Why? Because the principle of renunciation
is explained by Prabhupada as a living being renounces something for gaining something more
valuable. For example, a student sacrifices his childish proclivities to gain better education.
As children are sent to school, initially, they may be very, very playful. But as they
become mature and serious, then they actually try to gain better knowledge.
So,
they are given up their playful tendency. Similarly, a servant gives up his job for
a better job. So, in the same way, a devotee renounces the material world, not for nothing,
not to become empty handed, without any possessions,
know, but for something tangible in spiritual value. So, devotee gives up material possessions
to gain some spiritual, spiritually tangible value, something of spiritual value and it
is quite tangible, it is not intangible. So, the example is given of the Goswamis of Vrindavan
who were disciples of Chaitanya Mahaprabhu. It is said here, Srila Rupa Goswami, Srila
Sanatana Goswami and Srila Raghunath Das Goswami and others gave up their worldly pomp and
prosperity for the sake of service of the Lord. Devotion is service.
For Krishna Bhakti, for Krishna Seva for that reason. They were big men in the worldly sense.
The Goswamis were ministers in the government service of Bengal. Rupa Goswami and Sanatana
Goswami are ministers of Nawab Hussain Shah in the then government of Bengal during that
time. And Srila Raghunath Das Goswami, who was the
son of a big zamindar of his time. Very, very rich. His father was very rich. But they
left everything to gain something superior to what they previously possessed. So, don't
think that devotees are renouncing and giving up and becoming totally impoverished. No,
they give up material wealth to gain some spiritual wealth.
The devotees are generally without material prosperity, but they have a very secret treasure
house in the lotus feet of the Lord. So, this treasure possessed by the devotees is

him. A touchstone can convert any base metal to gold simply by touching. In Hindi they

with a touchstone, it become gold.

So, Sanatana Goswami, he had a touchstone with him and he had left this stone, touchstone in a pile of refuse, in some garbage. He had thrown it in the garbage. A needy man took it.

So, somebody approached Sanatana Goswami, I am a very poor man. So, can you give me something so that I can get rid of my poverty? So, Sanatana Goswami said, you want some touchstone? It is there. You can take it.
Where is it? Oh, it is in the garbage heap. So, this poor man, he took it and he thought, oh, now my...
Poverty problem is solved completely. But later on, he wondered, why was this valuable stone, this touchstone kept in such a neglected place? Why was it kept there?
He was an intelligent person also. He was considering that what kind of thing I have taken from the Goswami, from Sanatana.

He therefore asked Sanatana Goswami for the most valuable thing. He was intelligent enough to understand, if touchstone is the most valuable thing Sanatana Goswami has in his possession, then he would not have left it in the garbage.

Nobody leaves in the garbage something very, very valuable that they possess. So, why had he kept it in the garbage? So, therefore, he went and asked Sanatana Goswami that can you give me the most valuable thing in your possession?
Sanatana Goswami said, yes, I can give you. And what did he give? Sanatana Goswami gave him the holy name of the Lord.
That is why in one of the scriptures, it is said, Nama Chintamani Krishna. Krishna Nama is the spiritual touchstone. It is not a material touchstone. It is a spiritual touchstone.

When somebody advances materially, material advancement is civilization. Such material advancement is a great stumbling block for spiritual advancement. The more one becomes materially advanced, the more one becomes puffed up.

And consequently, such a puffed up person cannot make spiritual advancement even if such a person takes to chanting Hare Krishna. Because the chanting will be done without the sincere feeling. That is not possible for a materially intoxicated person.
Such material advancement entangles the living being in the bondage of material body followed by all sorts of material miseries.
See, material advancement comes with a price. What is that? With material advancement, there is entanglement and entanglement means material miseries.
So, this has to be carefully understood. So, therefore, in Sanskrit, material advancement is called Anartha, unwanted things, unwanted.
Actually, this is so. This is a fact. Material advancement is Anartha. It is not required.
